summary: This document is an internal email chain and incident report from July 23, 2019, detailing the discovery of Jeffrey Epstein in his cell with red marks on his neck, his claim that his cellmate attempted to kill him, and his subsequent placement on suicide watch. It includes medical and psychological assessments and discussions about his potential transfer to general population.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate found in his cell in a fetal position with red marks on his neck, claiming his cellmate attempted to kill him. He was placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Shirley V. Skipper-Scott
persons.context: Appears as the sender of an email in the forwarded chain regarding the Epstein incident.

connections.description: Skipper-Scott is involved in the email chain reporting on the incident involving inmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on the floor in a fetal position in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with red marks on his neck. He was unresponsive initially, placed in restraints, and escorted to a suicide watch cell.

events.title: Medical Assessment of Epstein
events.description: At 6:30 a.m., a Physician Assistant medically assessed Epstein. He was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling, but had a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck and a small mark on his left knee. He claimed not to know what happened.

events.title: Psychological Assessment and Suicide Watch
events.description: At 9:10 a.m., a psychologist evaluated Epstein and determined he would remain on suicide watch for further observation.

events.title: Review for General Population Placement
events.description: Following the incident, staff began reviewing Epstein's case for potential placement in the general population in Unit 7 South and were looking for an appropriate cellmate.

locations: 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with red marks on his neck, claiming his cellmate had attempted to kill him.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident, where he was medically assessed and found to have a circular erythema (redness) around his neck but denied pain or knowledge of the event.
Epstein informed staff that he had already told his attorney about the alleged harassment and attempted killing by his cellmate prior to the incident.

Internal emails show confusion and a request for a clearer memo on Epstein's actions, status, and plans for his potential move to general population to be forwarded to higher authorities (IPPA and the Director).
The document indicates an active administrative process to move Epstein out of the SHU and into the general population at the time of the incident.
